A local council candidate has urged the SNP-led Scottish Government to delay the implementation of rules that could require homeowners to spend hundreds of pounds on new smoke alarms.
Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour candidate for West Fife & Coastal Villages, has urged a delay in the implementation of the regulations requiring all homes to have an inter-linked system of smoke alarms and heat detectors so that financial support can be made available for those who might struggle to afford such a high cost.

Furthermore, he says a shortage of supply could stop even those who can afford from complying in time, putting their home insurance at risk were their property to be damaged by fire in the meantime.
Commenting on the policy, Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour candidate for West Fife & Coastal Villages, said:
“With energy prices increasing and Tory tax rises on the horizon for working people, and with local suppliers telling me of a shortage of units, the SNP must think again about the best way to implement this important policy.”
“I want to see a delay so we can work together to put in place financial support for people who will struggle to afford this equipment. If we don’t provide that support, we risk creating a group whose houses are less safe and could find it difficult to claim on their home insurance in the event of a fire.”
“Everyone wants to get this fixed so let’s have a short delay, sit round a table and figure out the best way to support people and get this change implemented properly.”

Comrades, I have bad news. The electorate think Scottish Labour is out of touch and that the party arrogantly believes it is special and somehow morally superior to other political parties.
You know why? Because we are out of touch and arrogantly believe we are special and somehow morally superior to other political parties.
I worked on the campaigns in 2007, 2011, 2016 and 2021. After each of those four elections I heard elected members, candidates, staff or activists utter phrases like “they will come back to us”, “they don’t know that they’ve done”, “they don’t understand”, “just give them time.” If that isn’t arrogant and presumptive then I don’t know what is.
At the same time, we, and I am as guilty of this as anyone, we reel off broken SNP promises, things they haven’t achieved, targets they have missed, what we see as dirty tricks or dishonest campaigning and then look on in disbelief as Scottish Labour lose yet another election. We think we are better than, purer than, above, beyond, the other parties or in a different realm altogether. It’s someone else’s fault, if only they would understand.
Well, I have more news. We are not better than any other party, we are not purer, we are not in some kind of elevated position. We are in the same scrap for votes as they are. We want to win so we have the opportunity to put our values in to practice and help people. That’s politics.
No more was this obvious than during the most recent election. During the campaign, Scottish Labour introduced a new slogan, “people deserve a better government and better opposition.” Now, it was obvious to absolutely anyone that Scottish Labour were not going to sweep to power, with Anas Sarwar installed as First Minister after 7 May. And yet the response to bluntly stating this fact was not exactly universal acclaim. “We are giving up on winning”, “We shouldn’t concede”, “What’s the point if you aren’t in it to win.” I heard all of these things and more.
So why did this slogan cause such grumping? Because it pierced the bubble of our self-delusion and said what the voters themselves already knew. We weren’t going to win but we would try and improve the lives of people in Scotland no matter the result.
We had no divine right to anyone’s vote, we were going to fight for them all, we knew we had fallen far and had a long way to come back. I was told this on the phones and on the doors when people heard that slogan. “At least you understand”, “You know how far you have to go” and, my favourite, “I might listen to what you have to say.” Hardly a ringing endorsement, but perhaps a start.
We need to build on that when the council elections roll round again next year, always remind ourselves that we don’t have the automatic right to any vote but neither should any vote seem out of reach. Honesty, positivity and aspiration should be at the heart of everything we say.
No grumping, no complaining, no bemoaning lies or dirty tricks by our opponents. Show voters we are on their side, will stick with them, we will help them no matter the result. That we want to earn their votes and demonstrate that we deserve their votes through our words and actions in and out of power.

Welcome
It is the greatest honour of my life to be elected to serve as your Member of Parliament for the Dunfermline and Dollar constituency. I will do everything I can to serve you and your family and deliver for our communities.
The Dunfermline and Dollar constituency blends a rich history, vibrant communities and a future of dynamic growth. It includes Scotland’s newest city, Dunfermline, once a royal capital and now a thriving urban centre. Rosyth is home to a major naval dockyard, playing an ever-growing role in UK shipbuilding and defence. Our picturesque towns and villages, Dollar, Muckhart, Kincardine, Saline and Limekilns, add character to our area, offering a unique mix of heritage, natural beauty and local pride. Our former mining towns of Oakley, High Valleyfield and Comrie reflect the area’s industrial heritage and contribute to the resilience of our communities, as well as our proud working-class roots and strong sense of identity.
If you are a constituent and wish to contact me, you can do so by emailing me at graeme.downie.mp@parliament.co.uk or calling 01383 332841. My team and I will be happy to assist you with any enquiries or concerns you may have.
On my website, you can keep up to date with my work and constituency visits right across Dunfermline and Dollar as well as my contributions at Westminster, standing up for you in Parliament.
About Graeme
I live in the constituency on the West Fife coast with my wife and two daughters. Before being elected as the MP for Dunfermline and Dollar, I served as a councillor for West Fife & Coastal Villages and ran my own business.
My dad was an electrician all his working life – for the nationalised Electricity Board, the railways, the armed forces, and at Edinburgh Castle and Holyrood Palace. My mum worked in clerical and administrative roles across construction, insurance, and higher education. My sister is a Clinical Psychologist in our NHS.
I was one of the first in my family to go to university. I got there through hard work and ambition – but I also got there because of great teachers and the opportunities provided by a good state school. Without public services like those, my journey would have been far more difficult, if not impossible.
The people of Dunfermline and Dollar voted for change – for a better future where everyone has the chance to achieve their ambitions. I will never be ashamed of being ambitious – for my community, for Fife, and for Scotland.
As your MP, I’m determined to help create a society where the opportunities my parents worked so hard to give me – and which successive Labour governments helped to deliver – are available to everyone.

A campaign to reverse a decision to withdraw funding for a new health centre in Kincardine is gathering momentum after a public meeting this afternoon secured the support of a leading MSP.
The meeting was organised by Cllr. Graeme Downie, Fife Labour Councillor for West Fife & Coastal Villages and heard from Jackie Baillie MSP, Shadow Cabinet Secretary for NHS Recovery, Health and Social Care.
Jackie Baillie gave her support for the campaign and pledged to raise the issue at Holyrood with SNP Health Secretary Michael Matheson.
Cllr. Downie gave an update on the current situation including:
- The current health centre is a cottage built in the early 20th century.
- A report in 2016 confirmed it was not fit for purpose for reasons including a lack of disabled access, no storage and insufficient space.
- Scottish Government and NHS Fife agreed a plan and funding for a new health centre in the village which would better serve the growing population of the area and bring more services together.
- In March 2023, the SNP announced they were delaying their funding until “the second half of the decade” because it was no longer a priority.
- Other projects in Fife affected by the delay include plans for a new health centre in Lochgelly.
- Despite approaches from local people, Health Secretary, Michael Matheson MSP, has refused to meet with local people to explain the decision.
Speaking after the event Cllr. Graeme Downie said: “It is outrageous that the person responsible for breaking their promise to the people of Kincardine to provide a new health centre is too scared to come and explain that decision to the community.
“It would only take a small diversion of his Ministerial car but Michael Matheson is unwilling to even do that.
“I am delighted to have the support of Scottish Labour and Jackie Baillie MSP and I am sure with her help at Holyrood we can continue to press the SNP Scottish Government to do the right thing and bring back the funding that this centre so desperately needs.”
Commenting, Scottish Labour Health Spokesperson Jackie Baillie said: “For too long people in Kincardine have been let down by an SNP government that is out of ideas and out of touch.
“This health centre is vital to the local community, but Mr Matheson has not even taken the time to explain this decision to the people he’s letting down.
“I will be raising this issue in Holyrood and hope to hear from Mr Matheson soon.”

Attempts by NHS Fife to plug gaps in GP services with locums are falling short, according to a Fife Labour Councillor, who wants more information about how other interventions can maintain a high level of care for people and communities.
Figures obtained through a Freedom of Information request by Cllr. Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour Councillor for West Fife & Coastal Villages, show an average of four locums covering 25 sessions each month since January 2021.
With each session intended to last four hours and 10mins, that means approximately just 13 days of additional GP cover across the Kingdom being provided by locum GPs.
NHS Fife has regularly posted on social media about reduced services at GP surgeries across the Kingdom.
Cllr. Downie wants more detail about how multi-disciplinary teams, which NHS Fife say can provide a very high standard of care without the need to see or speak to a GP, will work and reassurance that the staff exist to fill those teams.
Commenting on the figures, Cllr. Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour Councillor for West Fife & Coastal Villages said:
“In just the last month, NHS Fife have posted four warnings on their Facebook page about reduced services at GP surgeries across the Kingdom.”
“We are told there is a shortage of GPs nationwide and clearly there are not enough locum doctors to fill the gaps either.”
“At Valleyfield Practice in my own Ward which has had extensive problems over recent years. Patients were reassured in a letter on 1 July that a multi-disciplinary team is being deployed to maintain service levels.”
“I trust that could be the case but people need to know what the composition of those team might be and that NHS Fife have the staff to fill them. Only then can people and communities feel properly assured.”

A local Councillor has one again urged Scottish Health Secretary, Michael Matheson MSP, to meet with the local community in Kincardine to explain his government’s decision to refuse funding for a new Health Centre, initially promised in 2016.

That funding is now unlikely to appear until at least the end of the decade, or even later.
More than 300 people in Kincardine have now signed a petition online or in person urging the Health Secretary to reverse this decision and provide funding for the new health centre immediately.
It comes as press reports indicate Mr. Matheson will visit Lochgelly Health Centre, who has also been refused funding, after pressure from Fife Labour (https://www.centralfifetimes.com/news/23506789.government-minister-visit-dilapidated-health-centre/)

“I am delighted that pressure from Fife Labour colleagues means Mr. Matheson will visit Lochgelly to explain why his government has broken its promises on funding, yet he refuses to explain himself to people in Kincardine.”
“Mr. Matheson’s Ministerial Car will have to drive through Kincardine from his Falkirk constituency to get to Lochgelly. Why doesn’t he just stop on the way and explain why his government has broken its promise to people in Kincardine and what he is going to do to make sure they are still receiving proper medical services?”
Text of letter to Michael Matheson MSP
“Dear Mr. Matheson
I am writing, as I did to your predecessor, to ask you to meet with the local community in Kincardine to explain why promised funding for a new health centre in the village might not be provided until the end of the decade or even later.
I note your reply to the Leader of Fife Council, Cllr. David Ross (REF 202300351344), contained some excuses but I believe the people of Kincardine deserve an explanation in person and the opportunity to ask you some questions and, hopefully, receive some reassuring answers.
More than 300 people in Kincardine have signed a petition urging you to reverse your decision and provide funding immediately.
I note press reports that you intend to visit Lochgelly Health Centre which has also been denied funding in a similar manner. I hope during that visit you will meet with local Councillors and community groups to hear more about their concerns as well.
The people of Kincardine often tell me they feel forgotten by the Scottish Government and, given the proximity of your own constituency to the village, I hope you can find time to visit soon and explain your decisions to local people.
I look forward to hearing from you.
Yours sincerely,
Cllr. Graeme Downie”

Plans for a major site in Fife that could have delivered thousands of jobs and created training opportunities in areas of high unemployment are in ruins after the Scottish Government agency responsible for economic development admitted plans to bring high-speed train manufacturing to the site had ended.
In a letter to a local Councillor, Scottish Enterprise have admitted their option to purchase the site of the former Generating Station at Longannet, near Kincardine in Fife, had expired following confirmation from Talgo last year that they had been unsuccessful in the bid process for HS2.

Mr. Downie has likened the failure to the CalMac Ferry fiasco, saying the SNP are more interested in press coverage than helping people.

The Longannet site has fantastic road and sea links and the fact the Scottish Government have failed to prioritise realising this potential is an absolute scandal.”
“I wrote to the Chief Executive of Talgo two weeks ago asking for more information but have yet to receive a reply. Recently, I was listening to the final episode of my favourite podcast, Talking Politics, which is ending after six educational years. As the team of Professor David Runciman and the incomparable Helen Thompson neared the end of the recording, they listed the things they hadn’t been able to cover in that last episode. Remarkably, this included the future of the UK, the stability of American democracy and climate change. From the COVID pandemic to war in Ukraine, plus the spiralling cost of living and the climate emergency our politicans are not short of challenges although unfortunately we can sometimes find them short of solutions.
Climate change has been discussed routinely on the show and both hosts believe it will shape global politics of the next decades. But when politicians shaping policy try asking, “what will this mean for the climate?” the discussion becomes impossibly complex very quickly. On a geopolitical level, we seem to be pursuing a strategy of managed decline and praying for a miracle in the form of new technology. That isn’t good enough.
Politicians like to keep total control of issues like climate change, following a fallacy that large problems need large solutions. I would suggest large problems need large scaffolding but millions of small pieces of variety to complete the building. The latest research from the Fabians Talking Green shows that the public are supportive of climate action but the language of “net zero” and “green industrial revolution” do not resonate, with working class people and older people particularly less convinced of the economic benefits of taking action and more likely to prioritise protecting jobs over taking action on climate change.
So, instead of starting tackling climate change from the almost incomprehensible and unreachable concepts of a global problem, let’s start local.
President Joe Biden said, when he thinks “climate change” he hears “jobs.” Political shorthand to be sure but he is right. There are a few fringe voices suggesting we must choose between a prosperous economy and saving the planet but it is not a view I subscribe to. The job for progressives is to build a broad coaliton of support for climate action and talk about how we can improve peoples lives and job prospects.
In the ward where I am a candidate in May, West Fife & Coastal Villages, we have as clear a footprint of Scotland’s industrial heritage as you will find anywhere. From coal-mining communities like Oakley, Blairhall and Valleyfield, to Longannet, once the largest coal-fired power station in Europe, now being slowly demolished, with no firm plan for the future of the massive site.
This part of Fife quite literally powered the economy of Scotland and the UK for almost 40 years. From people to skills to raw material, to energy to supply chain, to the UK and European economy. Energy was what they did.
I know from speaking to people while campaigning that two things feature at the top of their priorities now. Their local economy and their local environment. If an area like this is seized by those two issues, surely the Venn Diagram of using local economies to improve climate is already there?
If we are to tackle climate change and hear “jobs” as President Biden does, we will need values like sustainable development and international cooperation but implemented in a way that begins to equalise power, wealth and opportunity. That takes it from the global scaffolding to the local rendering.
To do this, we must not only build trust but trust communities to shape their own local economies and local environments. Trust that they already share basic values of wanting better for their children, in both jobs and climate.
We must allow communities a greater say through more active, participatory democracy. We must demand better and fairer distribution of power and money to councils and on to communities.
Trusting in that fashion is difficult and, let’s be honest, risky, with no guarantees of success. But is focussing on local economies to meet a global environmental challenge really any riskier than the situation we find ourselves in, daunted by complexity and hoping for technology to save the day?

There is a tendency in opposition to decry all government ideas, call them unworkable or unrealistic. Afterall, oppositions are there to oppose. However, history shows that the most successful political parties steal and refine, from governments, think-tanks, charities, trade bodies, you name it. This can be to improve a policy or, as has happened more recently, take an issue and strip it for parts to create the appearance of having taken action.
During the last election campaign, we saw the SNP claim credit for numerous Scottish Labour policies such as free bus passes and, perhaps most gallingly, Monica Lennon’s Period Poverty Act. We are seeing it again as the SNP seek to implement their own plans for a National Care Service and I suspect we are going to see it once more as they take pieces from Pauline McNeill’s Fair Rents Bill and include them in a forthcoming Housing Bill.
Whilst this is infuriating, “we thought of that first” is not a particularly effective message. Voters only care who has delivered, or at least is seen to have delivered. The SNP has been ruthless and shameless at this and it should make us examine our own approach to policy theft.
Anas Sarwar has set what I believe is the correct path of constructive opposition to improve the lives of people in Scotland. That has been, is and, I hope, always will be the purpose of the Scottish Labour Party. We must scrutinise proposed legislation, seek to improve it and highlight the ways in which the SNP are back-sliding or not delivering, even if this approach means they will take credit for our amendments or our ideas. The anger at having our ideas stolen, watered-down and then poorly implemented should give us all the energy we need to know that we must get Scottish Labour back in to power and soon.
To do that, we must beat the SNP at their own game. We must steal back. Take policies the SNP ignore or do not want to act on but would improve people’s lives and make them our own. The SNP are particularly vulnerable to this because their unifying mission, a political strength to be sure, is also a strategic weakness. At the final decision point, they are more likely to shy away from any policy which diminishes the chances of independence.
For example, the SNP’s Social Justice and Fairness Commission, whose report was published last week, is framed as “building consensus towards a better Scotland with independence”. The strategic weakness exposed in the last two words.
The report itself contains a lot of policy ideas Scottish Labour might choose to develop ourselves. In fact, a couple of them are similar to policies in our own 2021 manifesto. That is where our opportunity lies.
While the SNP are trying in vain to build a consensus for independence, we can, and in some cases already are, build a consensus for; a Housing Land Corporation; for modernising housing stock; for better rewards for those working in social care; for effective anti-racist and pro-equality education and; targeted face additional barriers and challenges in finding and maintaining work.
To build that kind of consensus, we can reach across political parties and across political divides. It doesn’t happen overnight but we mustn’t be afraid to steal good ideas from wherever we find them.

As a local council candidate, what strikes me speaking to people is that everyone, regardless of age, gender, background or political affiliation, wants to make their community and country, however they identify that, better.
We know the divisiveness of the constitutional question has led many to believe nothing can be better without Scotland becoming independent, that’s not new. But a side-effect of our current polarisation is a reduction in understanding of the various different levels of government, and in voters confidence it can deliver better and fairer outcomes. The constitutional matters, nothing else.
At best that loss of confidence leads to sloppy governing, as I believe we are seeing at Holyrood now. Just keep banging the single question drum and no one cares what else you do. At worst, that level of tribalism can lead to corruption and the effective end to participatory democracy as voters excuse bad behaviour because of the answer to the binary distraction.
At local government level, I believe it is manifesting as disinterest among voters. This was evident in the recent polling by Our Scottish Future showing only a quarter of voters were confident they could name the leader of their local council. I think even that figure would drop further if we were to conduct a pop quiz to see if the 25% named the right person.
One of the many reasons for this, I believe, is a lack of attention and understanding of local government and what it does. Too many voters, when I have pointed out the role of councils in social care, economic development or education give me the same slightly blank look and talk about, you guessed it, potholes, bins and dog poo.
Those things are important to providing better communities but they can’t be where local government begins and ends and I don’t think this is the fault of Councillors or voters. I think the constitutional question is causing a cycle of decline.
Only focussing on the constitution has led to less interest in effective policy and governing at local level. That, understandably, causes frustration among Councillors and officials trying to govern and inevitably has a negative impact on delivery. Finally, poorer services further lowers voter expectation and convinces some of them only constitutional change can solve the ills and we start around again.
To break that cycle, we need to give local government its confidence back and raise voters expectations of it. Voters must know they can demand better and I know Councillors and officials are ready to deliver just that.
The elected Mayors or Provosts proposed by Our Scottish Future might be part of a solution but they are far from a silver bullet. We must be honest about that and not fall in to the same trap we have seen with the constitution. We need long-term public education that raises the profile and horizons of local government, to have constituents demand better of their Council and their Councillors.
That grassroots pressure can push up and raise standards at other levels, improving governance and policy implementation whichever party is in power at whatever level.

Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour candidate for West Fife and Coastal Villages, welcomed the announcement by Scottish Labour Leader, Anas Sarwar MSP and Deputy Leader, Jackie Baillie MSP, at the party’s annual conference which took place in Glasgow this weekend.
Under the plans, from 2023/24 future health and care Barnett consequentials will be used to cover the cost of residential care for older people aged over 65 – lifting a huge financial burden from the backs of thousands of Fifers.
Mr. Downie believes that by helping people get the care that they need in residential care, it will free up capacity in the NHS by preventing people from ending up in hospital when they don’t need to be there.
Better support in the community can prevent long delays to hospital discharge, reduce the need for hospital care at end of life and prevent unnecessary hospital admissions.
The vital importance of our social care sector has only become more apparent through the pandemic.
The announcement is part of a bold plan to build a National Care Service worthy of the name and fit for the future including:
- Delivering fair pay for social care workers, rising to £15 an hour.
- Plugging the gap in non-residential care funding identified by the Feeley Report.
- Investing in restoring and increasing respite care to support Scotland’s unpaid carers.
Commenting on the announcement, Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour candidate for West Fife & Coastal Villages said:
“I raised the issue of delayed discharge a few months ago with shocking statistics showing that over 50,000 people in Fife could spend longer in hospital than needed because of pressure on social care.”
“We need bold and immediate action to arrest the crisis we are already seeing in social care services in Fife and which seems will inevitably get worse if radical steps are not taken.”
“The announcement this weekend by Anas Sarwar and Jackie Baillie is exactly the kind of bold solution we need to tackle the crisis we see in our social care services. This plan would provide residential care to everyone over the 65 who needs it – free at the point of need – and I look forward to campaigning on this issue during the remainder of the campaign and beyond.”

You could almost hear the eyelid muscles of Scottish Labour activists straining last week as we stared at the results of the YouGov MRP poll that had just been published. Don’t let the eyelids shut. Keep those eyes open. Don’t blink or it might go away.
But no, it was most definitely real. The YouGov model showed Labour winning up to 23 seats in Scotland, as the SNP looked to being beaten back across the central belt (political belts are better than political walls, trust me!)
Not only would that result show a resurgence in Scottish Labour itself but it would make Keir Starmer’s own path to No.10 Downing Street that much easier.
The glow has remained, rightly tempered by the message of Anas Sarwar that the only poll that will matter is on Election Day, a day Scotland and the UK needs as soon as possible!
The other note of caution from the YouGov poll was the tight margin projected in many of those 23 seats.
This highlights the need to keep fighting for every vote, from every household. The margin between 10 Scottish seats and 25 or even 30 is tiny but elections are decided on such knife-edges.
The concentration of marginals in Scotland also means it will be more important than ever that we win positive support from voters. It is not enough simply for the Tories and SNP to lose, we must win and I don’t think we are quite there. Yet.
For example, The seat I am fighting, Dunfermline & West Fife, showed a margin of just 5% and that was towards the middle or high end of winning margins, with some under 1%. This seat lies in the new heartlands of Scotland, with young aspirational professionals on low to middle incomes perhaps in their first home, working hard to make ends meet.
To truly win this vital demographic voters to our side with enthusiasm, we will have to overcome a cynicism that has resulted from SNP failure. A feeling that if they couldn’t do it for them, what makes us think we can.
Voters might be realising that for the last 17 years, the SNP has painted a vision for the future in watercolours, easily washed away by the latest Scottish shower, dreich morning drizzle or sharp evening Haar.
But for us to turn those 1% margins in to 10% margins, we must show that we share the desire of voters for a positive future for Scotland. That we want Scotland to be aspirational, ambitious and filled with opportunities for them, their friends, their families, and their community.
What will win over those swing voters in the mass of Scottish marginals is showing them that when the Labour Party paints its vision for a positive future for Scotland, we will using something a lot more durable.
We must convince them we can make permanent changes and show them what will be delivered for Scotland by having two governments working for them, rather than against each other.
If we are to achieve that, we must be realistic, yes, but not bashful about the scale of our ambition. Places like Dunfermline can succeed by advancing what we are known for, be that defence engineering, manufacturing and maintenance, heritage and tourism or professional services.
The last Labour government saved the Rosyth shipyard and it remains the largest single employer in the constituency, with diverse and secure work for both construction and maintenance of military and civilian shipping.
Contrast that success with the massive empty site of the former Longannet Generating Station at the other end of the constituency, decommissioned in 2016 with the Tories and SNP in power and with no plans for its future use.
It is an ideal site for investment through the industrial strategy of an incoming Labour government, seeking to create thousands of jobs in the green economy. An opportunity to show the difference a Labour government can make.
This is the kind of contrast we must strike in Dunfermline and marginal seats across Scotland, tangible improvements that match the ambition of communities and will deliver opportunities for people to fulfil their aspirations.
If we can achieve that then on the Friday morning after a General Election, the only thing our eyes should have to worry about is perhaps just being a bit bleary and bloodshot!

A West Fife Councillor has welcomed the decision by Fife Labour Council to remove charges for bulky uplifts from this April.
Cllr. Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour Councillor for West Fife & Coastal Villages, said that the move will tackle the blight of fly-tipping, reduce pressure on recycling centres and help residents struggling with the cost of living crisis.
About 14,200 bulky uplifts take place each year in Fife, with almost 35,000 items collected over 2021/22, such as couches and mattresses that are too big to fit into a wheeled bin and cannot be transported to a recycling centre.
The pledge to abolish the charge sees Fife Labour fulfil one of its key election pledges from the election in May 2022.
Cllr. Downie says that fly-tipping is a particular problem in rural parts of Fife, with more verges and unmonitored space making it easier for people to dump things at the side of the road.
Commenting on the announcement, Cllr. Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour Councillor for West Fife & Coastal Villages said:
“It is fantastic news that Fife Labour is delivering on one of our key manifesto pledges to reduce the blight of fly-tipping in rural areas by abolishing the charge for bulky uplifts.”
“I have seen fly-tipping across West Fife since I was elected and in rural areas with woodland near the road or lay-bys this has been a particular problem and I am hopeful that this move will help tackle that problem.”
“People should continue to use the excellent recycling facilities where possible but this move will really help with items that are too large or for people who have no means to transport items to a recycling centre.”
Bulky uplifts will continue to be ordered online via www.fife.gov.uk/bulkyuplift and the current points system will continue to be used. Uplifts will be scheduled on a first come first served basis and 180 booking slots will be available on a daily basis to manage demand across Fife. The list of items that can be uplifted will remain the same and black bag landfill material will continue to be accepted.

After a Westminster election, The British Election Study (BES) can be invaluable in getting behind the punditry and perceived wisdoms to more fact-based lessons and analysis that political parties can use.
In 2017, the BES found there was no “youthquake” in favour of Jeremy Corbyn and, most recently, showed the beginnings of “realignment” in the 2019 election, now further evidenced in the Hartlepool and Chesham & Amersham by-elections.
It is welcome to see the beginnings of this type of study here with the Scottish Election Survey (SES) and I would urge anyone to read the blogs and tweets so far but there was one thing in particular that caught my eye.
We know that for Scottish Labour to hope to form part of a government in future, we must not only hold on to our existing, pro-Union, support but take at least a chunk of the SNP vote with us as well. Some have argued this requires us to embrace constitutional change but is that true? It has never made sense to be on the face of it anyway. Afterall, why would SNP voters who are committed to independence, vote for a party that was, at best, reluctant and unreliable supporters of the cause?
But what if there were a specific part of the SNP coalition we could target successfully without supporting another divisive referendum. Alongside independence, the SES found that for SNP voters key phrases were “a focus on Scotland” and “standing up for Scotland”. This was very similar to those who voted for Welsh Labour (substitute “Scotland” for “Wales” obviously), showing a party opposed to radical constitutional change could win those voters with the right message.
To appeal to this part of the SNP coalition, Scottish Labour would not have to back a referendum or independence but perhaps look to a more traditional metric, often cited as critical in US polling. Is a party or candidate “on my side”.
To be “on my side” isn’t about manifestos, policy delivery or even outcomes. It is more nebulous; you just know it when you see it. I think we saw the beginning of that message during the 2021 campaign. “What Unites us, not what divides us” and “recovery, not old arguments”.
The SES also indicates that the “yes” supporters are slightly softer on constitutional change. If that part of the SNP coalition start looking for another home in the next few years for whatever reason, Scottish Labour must already be there, “on their side” and willing to “focus on Scotland.”
To achieve that, we don’t just need a raft of policies, those policies must embody something more, a better Scotland than what we have today and the prospect of an even better Scotland for future generations. To use the SNP parlance, we have to demonstrate that we are stronger for Scotland. Our policies must show that we understand, really understand, not just what voters complain about but what they want to see.
We have to show them we support their aspirations for their careers, their family, their lifestyle, their communities, their services and, yes, for Scotland as a whole. We have to be on Scotland’s side.

Dunfermline should be the “New Capital” for innovation, investment and economic growth in Fife while delivering excellent public services for communities, according to a local Councillor.
Scottish Labour Councillor Graeme Downie made the comments after speaking to Cllr. Downie believes the pieces are all in place for Dunfermline to become a driver of the future economy of Fife.
Cllr. Ross attended Scottish Cities Week in London last week (23-26 January). The event, organised by the Scottish Cities Alliance, enables Scottish cities to showcase their investment potential to a wide range of national and international investors and developers.
Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour Councillor for West Fife & Coastal Villages, said:
“It is time for the people of Dunfermline to be offered a vision for a new, optimistic and positive future and for that vision to be delivered.”
“We need to build on the incredible legacy of Dunfermline Labour leaders like Helen Law who worked tirelessly to secure the city status that Dunfermline so clearly deserved.”
“Dunfermline has a proud history as Scotland’s capital, as a centre for innovation, arts & culture, education, philanthropy and social change but now we have to look to the future.”
“We need to deliver the change that people in this city thirst for, to put Dunfermline at the centre of Scotland’s economic success, with public services that deliver for communities.”
Labour Councillor David Ross, Leader of Fife Council, said:
“I was very pleased to be able to represent Dunfermline at Scottish Cities Week in London last week, as Scotland’s newest city once again took its rightful place alongside the other seven Scottish cities. It was a great chance to showcase what Dunfermline has to offer in its people, skills and investment opportunities.”
“As the Labour Administration of Fife Council, one of our top priorities is to develop the local economy, encouraging growth and making sure that everyone benefits from the wealth generated within our communities. A key part of this is developing the vision for the future of Dunfermline, putting the new city at the centre of the future success of the rest of Kingdom and the wider region.”
“The Labour Council is already promoting Dunfermline as a location to attract greater investment, create growth and compete internationally. A successful Dunfermline will benefit not only City residents but it is also critical for the rest of Fife and we need to work to make that a reality.”

A Fife Councillor has called for more support to help Home Care workers with rising petrol costs as part of Fife Labour Council efforts to mitigate the effects of the SNP / Tory recession.
Cllr. Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour Councillor for West Fife & Coastal Villages, who is also a member of the Fife Health & Social Care Board, has written to Council Health Spokesperson, Cllr. David Graham, asking for home care workers to be given the same 5p per mile allowance increase granted to NHS staff earlier this year.
Cllr. Downie has asked for the allowance to be increased immediately, payments to be backdated to April 2022 and for the support to continue for the remainder of the financial year.
In his email he points out cuts to local government budgets by the SNP Scottish Government and the unwillingness of the UK Tory government to take action but Cllr. Downie believes the Fife Labour Council must do all it can to help home care workers to prevent a staffing crisis.
Commenting, Cllr Downie said:
“Home care workers are essential to our health & social care system but they are being penalised because they have to use their cars to be able to help the most vulnerable in our society.”
“Home care workers should receive the same increase in petrol allowance of 5p per mile that NHS colleagues received back in April and this should be backdated so they receive the same level of assistance.”
“I have written to Cllr. Graham asking him to explore this issue in more detail as well as the feasibility of having this increase in place for the remainder of the financial year 2022/23.”
Full text of email to Cllr. David Graham.
“Dear Cllr. Graham
Thank you for your time earlier this week to discuss my concerns regarding the disparity in mileage allowances between NHS staff and home workers in my Ward and across Fife.
We discussed the difficulties of cuts to local budgets by the SNP Scottish Government in Edinburgh and the unwillingness of the UK Tory government to take action to help tackle the impacts of fuel increases.
I know these circumstances mean we are limited in the action we can take but I believe we must do all we can to help people with rising fuel and food costs, particularly in the face of the oncoming SNP / Tory recession.
You will be aware that in April 2022, NHS staff were given temporary increase of 5p per mile in their mileage allowance. As I mentioned to you I am concerned home care workers are being placed at significant disadvantage by not having the same increase granted to them.
This situation creates the possibility that our already under pressure social care services feel undervalued, leading to difficulty in maintaining and attracting staff to provide this essential services which looks after the most vulnerable people across Fife.
As I mentioned at our meeting, I am asking if you could explore the possibility of:
- Increasing the mileage allowance for home care works by 5p per mile.
- Backdating this increase to April 2022.
- Keeping this measure in place for the remainder of the financial year 2022/23.
I hope you will agree with me that Fife Labour must do all we can to support and help our social care staff even as the SNP and Tories sit on the sidelines.
I look forward to your response.”

I was delighted to be selected to be the Scottish Labour candidate for the seat where I live, Dunfermline & West Fife, likely to become Dunfermline & East Ochils after boundary changes.
It it is a very winnable seat in a General Election, but also could be a proving ground for a number of the messages the Labour Party need to get right if Keir Starmer is to become Prime Minister and have a majority which will allow real change across the country.
First, geographically, Dunfermline and West Fife is positioned perfectly to be a hub for growth, with Glasgow, Edinburgh, Stirling and Perth all within easy reach and the River Forth providing access to the North Sea.
Second, it is highly mixed and diverse. From former coal fields to the west, industrial sites at Rosyth, professionals services, customer services and the logistical giant of the Amazon distribution centre as you move east across the constituency.
It is also home to Fife College and integrated learning campuses under construction which can train and educate people of all ages to drive forward future success. All of this shows the constituency is a fertile ground for economic expansion, innovation and growth.
Finally, it is an area with one foot in the past, as the historical capital of Scotland, but that is looking towards the future as Scotland’s newest city, with the status officially conferred by King Charles last year.
Demographically, it represents the new heartlands of Scotland that Labour must win if it is to win big again in Scotland. Primarily, young aspirational professionals on low to middle incomes perhaps in their first home, working hard to make ends meet. Many may have voted SNP but are now frustrated with years of declining services and hard hit by a cost of living crisis.
They are not only looking for change but living in a place with all the ingredients to embrace that change and become a driving force for the rest of Scotland.
If we are to achieve that, we must not be modest when selling the potential of the area and its people. Nor should we be bashful about the scale of our ambition. Dunfermline can succeed by advancing what we are known for, be that defence engineering, manufacturing and maintenance, heritage and tourism or professional services.
The past 13 years of Tory government at Westminster and 16 years of SNP government at Holyrood has been characterised by areas being told success is only possible after something else happens first.
We were told by George Osborne that the pain of austerity that was required for growth, by the SNP that independence was needed for success and then again by Brexiteers that it was leaving the EU that was needed before people’s ambitions could be fulfilled.

The quote penned by novelist James Lane Allen “Adversity does not build character, it reveals it” applies about as clearly to the past two years of politics as perhaps at any time of the past.
It is therefore worth reflecting on what the responses over the past two years tells us about the character, and indeed values, of Scotland’s two ruling parties, the Tories and the SNP, and their leaders, Boris Johnson and Nicola Sturgeon. They must be considered in the same breath because these two parties and people, for good or bad, are the ones that have led us to this place.
But what was revealed about their instincts, their first reactions to a problem? Back in March 2020, we had the Prime Minister putting his fingers in his ears and pretending nothing was happening; missing COBRA meetings, rejecting a furlough scheme until the last minute, playing it all down, reverting to a mythical “Battle of Britain” spirit that somehow could shoot down Covid like Heinkel and Messerschmitt.
His and his party’s instincts were clear. A Party, in more ways than one, that wants to say “No”.
We saw it time and time again over the past two years, “No, we aren’t going to extend furlough”, “No, there won’t be another lockdown”, “No, Christmas won’t be affected.” You could hear the echos of Margaret Thatcher, “No. No. No.”
So to the other government that led us here, the SNP and their First Minister. In some ways their first reaction was worse. The first chance they had to reveal their character and values was the outbreak of Covid at a major Nike conference in Edinburgh. Their reaction? They didn’t just bury their heads in the sand, they actively sought to hide it! We can’t have this here first, this is a London thing at the moment. Always looking to create constitutional mileage out of every crisis.
I guess their secrecy was effectively implemented at least, taking months until the public knew anything about it but, when we did, it immediately showed the First Minister’s “Honest conversation” schtick as being a sham and not at all her true values.
Instead, the true values of the SNP exposed over the past two years though, is perhaps summed up by a small green puppet. No, not that one!
Instead, it’s the one that disappointingly muttered, “Always with you, it cannot be done.” Yoda may as well have been speaking to the First Minister rather than Luke Skywalker. I believe Nicola Sturgeon is fundamentally a good person but in the last two years, she has shown herself as the person who says “yes” a lot, but delivers little and always blames someone else for the stark shortcomings of her government.
Her instincts and values lead her to know what she should do and what people want her to do but then cynicism takes over and we see a half-baked intervention that sounds good but is overshadowed by blame and grievance. “The party that wants to say yes…. But doesn’t.”
Contrast both of these responses with the last time the Labour Party was in charge during a crisis, The banking crash of 2007 / 08.
Instead of pretending it wasn’t happening, Gordon Brown and his Chancellor, Alastair Darling, worked to build an international coalition, the type of which had rarely been seen before and certainly not since. Long hours, detailed work and a solution was found.
Now was that solution perfect? Absolutely not. Should the industry and individuals responsible been punished and conditions attached to their bailout? Of course they should. But a solution to that crisis meant wages were still paid, ATMs still worked and there was still cash to buy food.
In that case, the Labour Party’s response showed it’s values. Our first duty is to protect those most in need so just bloody get it done!
That crisis also showed another value. That helping those most in need should be done regardless of the political or electoral cost. The Prime Minister, Chancellor and others must have known that by intervening and saving banks, they were binding themselves to the bad guys in the public mind and would be punished by the electorate, as indeed they were. But still, the values were clear. Help the people who need it first and damn the politics. That is courageous leadership.
Compare and contrast the Labour values that were exposed in a crisis with the last two years of the Tories and SNP. Boris Johnson pretends a crisis isn’t happening, Nicola Sturgeon makes excuses for in-action. Only the Labour Party’s first instinct is to roll up its sleeves and do what is necessary to help those in need.

Another phrase that got me thinking this week was I realised I say “Is that helping?” a lot, often in sarcasm and with a wry smile. I was carrying heavy bags of soil in the garden and my wife duly added a trowel on top of them for me to take to the right place. This was met with a sarcastic “is that helping?” from me along with a wry smile.
It is one of those phrases where tone and context really are king, otherwise I might have ended up in the…compost.
“Is that helping?” is a phrase I think Scottish Labour need to use a lot more in any number of contexts and with a variety of different tones.
We need to earnestly ask, “is that helping?” when developing our policies and, if so, who is it helping. That moment of pause is helpful to stop our manifestos become laundry lists of commitments that sound good to us but perhaps won’t have the impact we first think.
We need to challenge ourselves and ask, “is that helping?” when deciding if a particular decision is contributing to a strategy or increasing our supporters.
We need to sceptically ask, “is that helping?” when being constructive in opposition. It is a good way to decide if a government policy deserves support or not. Is it tokenism or is it actually going in the right direction?
We need to forcefully ask, “is that helping?” when we see unhelpful contributions from our own side that take us off message and serve only as distractions.
And there should always be room for sarcasm so I am going to ask, “is that helping?” as I realise I should be in the garden and writing this may only have served as procrastination.

A West Fife candidate has called for the SNP to help address the rising cost of living by blocking proposed rises in water charges and providing an immediate Fuel Costs Payment to help those most in need meet the rising cost of energy.
Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour candidate for West Fife and Coastal Villages for the local elections on 5 May, has called for the SNP to review their approval of this year’s 4.2% increase in water charge rises and defer future rises until the current cost of living pressures have reduced.
Without intervention, this year’s rise would be followed by increases of an average of 2% above inflation until 2027, despite Scottish Water sitting on at least £400m in reserves.
Mr. Downie has also backed calls for the SNP to use £238 million of Barnett consequentials to provide an immediate Fuel Costs Payment that would put £400 in the pocket of those most in need to help them with sky-rocketing energy bills.
Commenting, Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour candidate for West Fife and Coastal Villages, said:
“With Tory Tax rises, growing inflation and increased energy prices, governments at Holyrood and Westminster must take action to help people in West Fife and across Scotland.”
“The SNP must immediately reverse their approval of a 4.2% rise in water bills and defer plans for future rises until some of the current cost of living pressures have abated.”
“The SNP should also use Barnett consequentials to provide an immediate Fuel Costs Payment to help those most in need meet rising energy bills.”
“Only the Scottish Labour Party is demanding action to make West Fife better and fairer. It is time for the Tories and the SNP to wake up and take action before we more people are struggling to make ends meet.”

Four West Fife Labour Councillors have written to the Chief Executive of Stagecoach demanding the company rethink plans to change services, urging them to instead invest in services to help people meet challenges caused by price rises across the economy.
Stagecoach published its revised plans last week and four councillors; Cllr. Graeme Downie (West Fife & Coastal Villages); Cllr. Cara Hilton (Dunfermline South); Cllr. Gordon Pryde (Dunfermline North); and Cllr. Andrew Verrecchia (Rosyth) have received calls, emails and social media messages from local people complaining about the changes.
In their letter to Martin Griffiths, the four Councillors say they are worried changes being proposed will add significantly to financial pressures people are facing and make it harder for them to maintain or access jobs and educational opportunities.
They highlight specific cases from commuters, wheelchair users and public service workers pointing out the problems with service changes.
Rather than cutting services, the four Councillors have asked for an urgent meeting with Stagecoach to discuss the proposed changes as well as how the company might consider increasing services to help people in West Fife handle an incredibly tough period by increasing the provision of bus services in this area.

Full text of letter (29 August 2022)
“Dear Mr. Griffiths
We are writing to you jointly as Councillors representing Dunfermline and West Fife to ask you to halt changes to Stagecoach’s timetable and, instead, invest in more services in the area to help people meet the difficult financial circumstances they face.
The changes being proposed will significantly add to financial pressures people are facing and make it harder for them to maintain or access jobs and educational opportunities.
Effective public transport is always an essential part of a successful economy but even more so at a time of sky-rocketing petrol prices and with the costs of energy, food and essentials increasing sharply.
As a result, more and more people will need to rely on your bus services in West Fife and to slash them in the way you are planning will add another concern to people and families throughout the area.
Since the launch of the consultation on these plans just a few days ago (23 August), we have been contacted by a number of our constituents worried about the effects they will have:
In particular, we have already heard from people in our areas worried about:
- Parents struggling to collect children from school or childcare because of the need to use a car or get a taxi which also adds significantly to cost.
- Harder for shift workers such as nurses and refuse workers that will find it harder to get to and from work late at night or early in the morning.
- Further reductions in rural bus services in West Fife making it harder to travel just a few miles between two villages, when that journey can already take up to two hours and is essential to use particularly health services in the area.
- Young people unable to access work and educational opportunities as they are less likely to have access to a car.
- Increased carbon emissions as people are compelled to use their car more
Specifically, we have been told of some specific concerns regarding the proposed changes:
- A person who finishes work in Edinburgh at 5pm will be unable to get home to Saline, a village in rural West Fife, until 8pm unless he pays for a taxi, which he can’t afford.
- A disabled woman in Abbeyview who will likely have to give up the job she loves as there will now be no bus serving her street and she is unable to walk the length of Aberdour Rd or through Abbeyview to get the proposed alternative service.
- Fife Council staff will be unable to travel by bus from Dunfermline to Bankhead because two early buses from the city to Glenrothes have been cancelled.
We would welcome the opportunity to meet with members of your team urgently to go through these issues in detail.
In addition to rolling back these specific changes, we hope to discuss how Stagecoach can help people in our communities through what will be an incredibly tough period by increasing the provision of bus services in this area.
We look forward to hearing from you very soon.
Sincerely,”

A General Election candidate has thanked farmers for their contribution to the local economy, enhancing food security and tackling climate change saying that, if elected, he will listen to and support the local farming community across the Dunfermline & Dollar constituency.
Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour Candidate for Dunfermline & Dollar for the UK General Election, visited James Adam’s cattle and sheep farm near Townhill, just outside Dunfermline, this week, at the start of lambing season.
During the visit to the farm, organised by NFU Scotland, Mr. Downie witnessed first-hand the dedication and hard work undertaken by Mr. Adam and his family in rearing lambs and cattle for market.
Fife boasts over 1,500 agricultural holdings, collectively employ over 3,000 people, with most of the jobs being full-time positions.
As well as seeing the new born lambs and cattle on the farm during the visit, Mr. Adam described the incredible produce made at other farms in West Fife, from fruit and vegetables to milk and cereals, demonstrating the range and scale of the farming sector in the Kingdom.
Commenting after the visit, Mr. Downie said:
“The commitment and hard work of people like James and his family is a critical component of our local economy but sometimes farmers feel they are overlooked or taken for granted.”
“But as well as supporting employment, farming in Fife is critical to improving food security and tackling climate change by providing more local sources of food, reducing reliance on importsand cutting back on food miles.”
“I am very grateful to James for allowing me to visit at such a busy time and to NFU Scotland for helping to organise. As I told James, if I am fortunate enough to be elected at the General Election this year, I will make sure that the contribution of farms and farmers in Dunfermline & Dollar is not forgotten.”

A West Fife Councillor has written to companies whose vehicles have been spotted speeding through a dangerous set of traffic lights in Kincardine, urging their drivers to be more careful.
The traffic lights and junction at North Road / Feregait / Toll Road in Kincardine is set to be redesigned as part of the regeneration of Kincardine High Street but Cllr. Downie believes companies have a responsibility to have their drivers slowdown in the meantime.
Constituents highlighted concerns over the traffic lights during recent surgeries and Community Council meetings in the village, prompting to Cllr. Downie to write to companies such as Openreach and Diageo urging them to get their drivers to slow down when approaching the junction.
Cllr. Downie said he had already received a positive response from Openreach who have briefed local engineering teams, reminding them of the importance to driving safety and reducing their speed. Diageo have also said they will look in to the issue in more detail with their contractors who go through the village on their way to and from their site in Alloa.
Cllr. Downie is urging local people to get in touch with him to highlight other companies speeding at the junction so he can contact them as well.
Commenting on the issue, Cllr. Downie, said:
“The traffic lights at North Road / Toll Road are a serious safety concern for people in Kincardine. There have been collisions at the junction between cars, vans and HGVs as well as near-misses with pedestrians.”
“It is right the lights and junction are being redesigned to make them safer but that will take time and it is important companies with vehicles who have come through Kincardine make sure their drivers are driving responsibly. Where possible I would urge companies to avoid using the village as a through route at all.”
“I want to thank both Openreach and Diageo for their positive response and the constructive way they have deal with my requests which I hope will see some improvements. I would ask people to get in touch and let me know of other poor driving in the area and I will follow-up with those companies as well.”

9,000 fewer young people in work in Fife since SNP came to power
Statistics published this week show almost 9,000 fewer young people in Fife are employed than when the SNP came to power in Edinburgh 14 years ago.
The statistics have been called “damning” by one local council candidate who has urged the Scottish Government to do more, including focussing on the regeneration of Longannet power station site to bring thousands of jobs to West Fife.
Graeme Downie, Scottish Labour candidate for West Fife and Coastal Villages believes places like Kincardine are being forgotten about and it is young people in particular who are suffering.
The statistics, published by Scottish Government, show that in October 2007 to September 2008, there were 23,500 young people (16-24) in employment in Fife. In October 2020 to September 2021, there were 14,900 young people in employment in Fife. That is a drop of 8,600, or 11.7% over the period.
Commenting on the statistics, Graeme Downie said:
“These statistics are absolutely damning and show that while the SNP are focussed on independence, young people in West Fife and across the region are suffering.”
“Almost 9,000 fewer young people in work has enormous consequences for them, their families and the future of places like Kincardine.”
“Just last week, we saw the main stack at Longannet come down but still no plan from the SNP about how they can use that site to deliver mass employment to the area.
“Speaking to residents, neighbours and family it is clear we are suffering a lost generation. Prospects are few, support is minimal and the SNP live in a denial about the harm their policies are causing.”
“West Fife has been forgotten about by the Scottish Government for too long. If elected I will immediately convene discussions with industry leaders on how best to implement a strategic plan for Longannet and to bring jobs for young people to the area.”
